Disappears is made up of some Chicago scene veterans-- Brian Case of garage-rock favorites the Ponys as well as several members of the defunct post-rock band Boas. Their music combines elements of both groups
column2: but it nearly became a casualty of the industry's current financial mess. Disappears were the very last act signed to Touch and Go before the label shut down
column3: and as a result
column4: their debut
column5: Lux
column6: was almost lost in the shuffle. Luckily they were eventually scooped up by Kranky
column7: and though their style differs considerably from the experimental and ambient that label is known for
column8: it seems a good fit for Disappears' dense and foreboding sound.

column1: Disappears' sound is a pared-down
column2: drone-heavy mixture of Velvet Underground scuzz
column3: garage-rock energy
column4: and krautrock propulsion. It may not feel like the most unique approach
column5: but
column6: importantly
column7: the band seems aware of that. Part of Disappears' appeal is that they've chosen to work within a set of stylistic and sonic limitations
column8: where vocals and instrumentation are stripped back to their most essential. It's more about minimalism and mastering the basics than making something brand-new.

column1: It works because Disappears keep things tight; even though there's heaviness and repetition in these tracks
column2: usually they're about three minutes long. ""Gone Completely"" is a killer opener
column3: a rush of fuzz-laden guitars and simple
column4: severe drumming. On this track and throughout the album
column5: frontman Case's vocals are buried in the mix just right-- his delivery is kind of a Britt Daniel-meets-Iggy Pop sing-speak-- and clouded in the feedback his words sound more powerful
column6: like they're trying to escape. The band mostly finds a comfortable zone and rides it
column7: but each track tweaks the formula just so
column8: and the mood stays jet-black dark throughout.

column1: Things do start to feel a bit same-y toward the end of the record. On ""Little Ghost"" and ""New Cross""
column2: it sounds like the band is revisiting ideas they touched on earlier. But when a group is working in such tight confines
column3: some overlap is natural. That the goal here is intentionally limited ultimately works for and against Disappears-- they achieve the sound they want
column4: and it does sound good
column5: but it's hard to think of Lux as much more than that
column6: because the components are so familiar. Still
column7:
that they're able to make these well-worn rock tropes feel quite so menacing after all this time is an achievement in its own right.

There have been some thorough examinations of post-punk-- Simon Reynolds' Rip It Up and Start Again being the most exhaustive-- but could any study ever be complete? The reservoir of out-of-print/never-in-print gems from the fertile late 1970s and early 80s would have to dry up
column2: and that hasn't happened yet. The last few years alone have seen excellent reissues of San Francisco's Units
column3: New York's Interference
column4: London's Lines
column5: and Georgia's Method Actors. Writing about the latter
column6: Pitchfork's Andy Battaglia guessed that the ""post-punk vault... would almost have to be empty at this point.""

column1: You'd think so
column2: but mere weeks after the Method Actors release
column3: Drag City has unearthed another treasure deserving of a new audience. Formed in Louisville in 1978
column4: the Endtables lasted less that two years
column5: releasing just one four-song EP while together. The Endtables compiles that EP
column6: a posthumous two-song single
column7: and six live tracks
column8: painting a quick
column9: sharp portrait of a band that sounded like they were in a hurry. Chugging along at a palpitating clip
column10: the group flies toward the sun of the Buzzcocks and Gang of Four
column11: but something about their hyper energy makes them a little more off-kilter than those groups. Like a sonic game of Jenga
column12: their tunes feel like they could spill into unruly cacophony at the slightest nudge.

column1: That never happens
column2: but it's not for lack of pushing and shoving by guitarist Alex Durig and singer Steve Rigot. Rigot in particular has a uniquely skewed rhythm
column3: biting off his words in strident yelps like the Undertones' Feargal Sharkey if you cut all of his lines in half. One of the best things about post-punk was the way many singers-- Ian Curtis
column4: Mark Mothersbaugh
column5: David Thomas-- turned technically imperfect voices into weapons through phrasing and attitude. Thomas may be the closest parallel to the bulbous Rigot
column6: who certainly deserves a place in that patchwork pantheon of inventive vocalists. Durig is equally creative
column7: slashing his chords across the songs like a whip across skin. But it's Rigot's delivery that gives these songs a mix of robotic staccato and wiry nerve.

column1: Highlights abound-- the engine-rev of ""Process of Elimination""
column2: the rubber-band snap of ""Circumcision""-- but the six studio songs are most notable for how little they deviate from the quality level established in the first note. The live tracks are less even-- endearingly earnest and raw but often rather illegible. A few little twists
column3: like an interlude of Clean-style garage swing in ""Europe""
column4: a song they never recorded in the studio
column5: hint at some other places this band could've gone. But as a self-contained document of a lightning-quick
column6: pretension-free moment in time
column7:
The Endtables is pretty spot on.

column9: on occasion

column4: idiosyncratic vision to a showier sound

column6: and it displays a far better understanding of how its moving parts should fit together than the more fleshed-out numbers on Daughters. It's more patient
column7: more deliberate

column4: and there are times when the band seems to be playing him
column5: rather than the other way around. As much as Destroyer is about excess
column6: Thief sometimes bites off more than Bejar could chew at that point
column7: and the duller bits obscure the moments of graceful abandon.

column3: every note falling into perfect order
column4: every word sung with the proper bite and bile. This is what Bejar was building to
column5: why he became a songwriter in the first place

column7: the drama is amped up to almost unthinkable levels
column8: and these tunes feel like a long series of exclamation points. The guy got really good really fast

column10: his observations are keen
column11: and his gaze is withering.

column1: Bejar's pop songcraft gets a real shot in the arm here; instead of burying his best lines in verses
column2: he builds his rave-ups around them
column3: and the songs feel like a series of unlikely peaks that

column9: ""one day I was playin' my old shit like 'who the fuck is this

Take a cursory look at the core of African pop music in the 1970s
column3: and Zambia's ""Zam-rock"" scene might seem a bit out of place. With township music to the south; Afrobeat

column5: and juju going on Northwest; and soukous thriving just over the northern border

column8: Zam-rock's fuzzed-out
column9: psych/proto-metal bent shouldn't be that surprising. Neither should the fact that so little of it actually came to the surface until recently; if a dedicated ethnomusicologist is going to take a trip to central Africa
column10: it's probably not to bring back albums that sound like Blue Cheer's Vincebus Eruptum.

column1: Which brings us to a more interesting facet about Zam-rock besides how out of place it initially seems: how out of time it actually sounds. Africa
column2: the sole album by Kitwe five-piece Amanaz
column3: is one of the better examples of the genre's style
column4: and how it was both behind and ahead of its era. It was released in 1975
column5: rock's weird no-man's-land period between glam and punk
column6: but its buzzing riffs and noodly solos place it a bit closer to 1969. That said
column7: it's hard to pinpoint their exact influences
column8: and the ones that come to mind at first listen seem like some kind of projection: if few people in the States or Europe bought albums by the Stooges or the Velvet Underground when they first came out
column9: what's the likelihood that they made it to a Zambian audience even five years later? Yet you get a Ron Asheton wah-wah snarl in ""Making the Scene""
column10: and there's a pretty Sterling Morrison-style lead guitar on ""Sunday Morning""-- which
column11: besides sharing a title with a popular Velvets song
column12: also sounds eerily like ""Oh! Sweet Nuthin'"".

column1: But it could all just be the shared byproduct of recording straightforward
column2: low-budget rock in an economically depressed environment. For all their cursory musical similarities with the same bands that inspired punk rock
column3: Amanaz were fairly unassuming
column4: even through all the fuzztone. Unassuming in this case doesn't necessarily mean unambitious-- on record
column5: they sound like a band that wanted to ply their trade in heavy rock
column6: folk-pop
column7: and funk all at once-- but there's a rawness on this album that gives it a familiar garage-band appeal. Rhythms shift from minimalist plod-stomps one track to supple grooves the next; lead singer Keith Kabwe's voice sometimes stretches past his melodic range into an off-key flatness that would be more off-putting if it didn't sound so spontaneous
column8: and it's all recorded with a muddy fidelity that
column9: if reminiscent of bedroom tape culture
column10: doesn't do the music any favors by turning what could've been a wall of guitar squall into a flimsy chain-link fence.

column1: Not like much of that can be helped or even really matters
column2: since Africa is one of those albums we should at least consider ourselves lucky to even get a chance to hear. Kabwe had retired to a life of farming by the time this album was proposed for reissue
column3: and out of the other four band members
column4: only guitarist Isaac Mpofu still survives. So hearing Kabwe wail
column5: ""Lemme tell you something new/ About the history of the man/ He's got nothing to lose
column6:
in ""History of Man"" resonates a bit more knowing just how little was saved from the Zam-rock scene for future posterity and how close to impermanence Amanaz's music actually came.

Having bounced from the four-piece outfit Miss Alex White and the Red Orchestra
column3: Ms. White has joined forces with drummer and brother Francis to strip down what little excess was clinging to her soul-inflected garage rock.<span> It's great fun to see the redheaded siblings headbanging like matching ""Fraggle Rock"" puppets in their ecstatic live show
column4: but White Mystery holds up as more than a concert flyer. Austerity is less a choice than a necessity for the duo: The guitar goes from dirty-sounding to dirtier-sounding
column5: the hooks are straightforward and stupidly catchy

column1: Don't be dissuaded by other

column3: he's a more accomplished player but less present as a personality. As the band's rhythmic anchor
column4: he's nearly as unbuttoned as Alex with his instrument
column5: and uses tracks like ""Overwhelmed"" to play drum fills that last for the entire songs. When he contributes a vocal

column1: White Mystery is almost too long; what could have been eight to 10 single-release-worthy tracks is 14 almost exhausting ones. The same basic elements can be fatiguing

column11: just like subtlety
column12:
holds very little import on White Mystery's debut.

When Elliott Smith's final studio record
column2: <i>From a Basement on the Hill
column3: was released in 2004
column4: some people wanted to avert their eyes. It emerged in the aftermath of his stabbing death the year before
column5: during which the shock over his gruesome death was compounded by troubling revelations. We were hearing about spiraling drug problems
column6: ambiguities in his autopsy
column7: and his fraught relationship with his family. For Smith's hardcore fans
column8: the album's very existence was charged. Smith's family had assumed the task of completing the record and several contentious artistic decisions were made
column9: including bringing in longtime producer Rob Schnapf and Joanna Bolme to finish a number of Elliott's songs that had been recorded as demos. At the time
column10: the final result felt too hot to touch
column11: and it remains the uneasy outlier in Smith's discography to this day.

column1: It was a sad fate for what had been shaping up to be the most sprawling
column2: ambitious record of Smith's career. Whatever troubles may have been plaguing his personal life at the time
column3: Smith seemed thrilled at the direction his music was taking.  In interviews
column4: he exulted in having discovered a ""big"" sound that made sense for him-- one that squared his expanding ambitions with his demand for pin-drop intimacy. His previous record
column5: Figure 8
column6: coated his songs in a blinding sheen that suited him as poorly as the rumpled all-white tux he'd worn to the Oscars. Basement saw him recoiling from that polish without abandoning his dream of a bigger sound
column7: and whatever else it might be
column8: it's the most complete document we have of the music he was hearing in his head those final years.

column1: The opening of ""Coast to Coast"" immediately gives us an idea of the changes Smith had in mind. After 40 seconds of haunted carnival music
column2: a brambled wall of guitars presses in from all sides
column3: with Smith's wounded tenor emanating weakly from the center. Everything  feels uncomfortably
column4: purposefully too-close; with mics pressed up against the instruments
column5: every twitch and scrape is crystalized. The mix is startlingly vivid: When the first guitar is strummed on ""Pretty (Ugly Before)""
column6: the chord doesn't ring so much as bloom
column7: suffusing the song with soft light. ""Strung Out Again"" is a lurching waltz
column8: with Smith's guitar lines creaking and stumbling into wrong notes. Elliott's voice
column9: in this context
column10: has never sounded lovelier or more ruined. No beautiful sound escapes without scars.

column1: Smith wrote with painful economy and eloquence about his own shortcomings
column2: and his words cleaved through bullshit with bracing force. During the Basement on the Hill sessions
column3: he began writing about his drug problems and depression with an unprecedented clarity. It seemed like an implicit rise to the challenge he posed himself in ""Strung Out Again""
column4: where ""Just looking in the mirror/ Will make you a brave man."" He sings calmly and directly about terrifying scenarios. After years of rehabilitation and relapse
column5: he had boiled the exhausting cycle of lifelong addiction down to eleven brutal words: ""Took a long time to stand/ Took an hour to fall.""

column1: The context is part of the reason listening to From a Basement on the Hill felt somewhat indecent in 2004. Now
column2: Kill Rock Stars is re-releasing the album alongside a remastered reissue of his 1994 debut
column3: Roman Candle
column4: situating the two records as bookends to an extraordinarily fertile career that may even help the volatile Basement on the Hill settle in more comfortably alongside the rest of Elliott's work.

column1: Roman Candle
column2: for its part
column3: remains a fan favorite
column4: and it contains some classic Smith songs: ""Condor Ave""
column5: the title track
column6: and ""Last Call""
column7: in particular. And yet it mostly serves to point to all that Elliott would later become. It's wispier and more diffuse than his self-titled or Either/Or
column8: and nothing here is as indelible as ""Needle in the Hay""
column9: ""The Biggest Lie"" or ""Ballad of Big Nothing"". A few of the ""No Name"" song sketches drift in and out without leaving much of a mark-- Smith's music would become fuller
column10: and his harmonic language more confident
column11: on subsequent albums.  The sound is there
column12: though
column13: unmistakable from the first note: the defeated whisper of the vocals
column14: the deceptively intricate guitar work
column15: and the angry little mantras (""leave alone
column16: leave alone
column17: 'cause you know you don't belong here"").  From these beginnings
column18: Smith would experiment with how much he could add to this framework without crushing it; on From a Basement on the Hill
column19: he found a thrilling new plateau. Sadly
column20:
we can now only imagine where he would have gone from here.

column3: Mulatu Astatke was one of the driving forces behind the transformation of the Ethiopian music scene from one of state-sanctioned bands to independent groups that played at nightspots around Addis Ababa. As an arranger
column4: he devised backing tracks for many of the country's popular singers
column5: and as a solo artist he forged an unorthodox path of his own
column6: developing a unique Ethio jazz style. It had at its core fundamental Ethiopian musical concepts
column7: the pentatonic scale first and foremost. But Astatke
column8: the only vibraphonist on the Addis scene
column9: mixed these sounds with the jazz
column10: Latin music
column11: and psychedelia he'd picked up during his time at music schools in the U.S. and Britain to make something new.

column1: As important as he was to Ethiopian pop's golden era
column2: Astatke's solo recordings were never commercial successes
column3: and they remained little-heard outside his home country until Buda Musique's Ethiopiques series devoted its fourth volume to him in 1998. The cover showed him with Duke Ellington during the latter's 1973 visit to Addis
column4: which was apt-- his own music had an Ellingtonian richness and sense of texture. Since that release
column5: interest in his music has steadily grown. In the last few years
column6: Astake got himself back in the game
column7: heading to Harvard University on a Radcliffe Institute fellowship
column8: where he worked on an opera and a modernization of the krar
column9: a traditional Ethiopian stringed instrument. Last year
column10: he cut an album and toured with London's Heliocentrics
column11: and on Mulatu Steps Ahead
column12: he works with them again
column13: as well as Boston's Either/Orchestra
column14: to take his music to a few places it's never been before.

column1: For one thing
column2: much of Astatke's past music
column3: especially his classic stuff
column4: was much more structured and stately than what he does here. It's as though he's come out of his Ellington period and he's moving into a looser
column5: more improvisational realm. The band eases into the album with ambient opener ""Radcliffe""
column6: guys in a room gathering steam together
column7: and the sound coalesces on ""Green Africa"". By the time they get into ""The Way to Nice""
column8: they're hammering out a swinging groove.

column1: The way the saxes wind through pentatonic themes in unison on ""Mulatu's Mood"" recalls classic Astatke
column2: and they give a solo to the bass sax and another to a kora
column3: a West African harp that Mulatu drags across the continent and seamlessly inserts into his own music. He reaches way back into his own catalog on ""I Faram Gami I Faram""
column4: a tune he originally wrote and recorded in New York in 1966. The combination of Ethio jazz texture
column5: Latin rhythm
column6: melismatic Ethiopian lead singing and salsa backing vocals is amazingly natural
column7: and it's a much more distinctive version than the original
column8: which features a more typical boogaloo vocal.

column1: It's great to hear Mulatu himself stretching out
column2: soloing on ""Ethio Blues"" and creatively filling out the chords elsewhere. Anyone who's liked his music in the past is very likely to enjoy this
column3: but I think Mulatu Steps Ahead will broaden Astatke's jazz following as well
column4: and frankly
column5: it's a much more coherent record than a lot of heavily improvisational modern jazz albums. It's a very easy album to access for listeners who aren't particularly schooled in either jazz or the Ethiopiques series as well
column6: moving an old
column7: appealing sound forward and outward. It's a pleasure to hear a man of Mulatu's age and past accomplishments push himself artistically like this
column8:
and it will be interesting to see where his music goes next.

A flop-eared rodent frolics in a lush field. In from the horizon sweeps a black cloud
column2: kicked up by an army of similar-looking rodents. That's the basic set-up of Varmints
column3: a 24-minute film by Studio AKA animator Marc Craste
column4: based on a book written by Helen Ward and illustrated by Craste. Jóhann Jóhannsson draws the title of his latest album from the book
column5: and this is the music he composed for the film's soundtrack. There's quite a bit of extra material-- the album is a full 15 minutes longer than the film-- but there's really no padding. And in the Endless Pause There Came the Sound of Bees works as a suite and doesn't require knowledge of the film or even the film's existence to work as a recording

column1: As a recording
column2: the album displays a few sides of Jóhannsson we haven't heard before. Among his albums to date
column3: it's one of the most musically active
column4: and befitting its origin

column6: which means something for a guy working in a genre frequently referred to as cinematic. We first got to know the Icelandic composer through two brilliant minimal electro-orchestral albums

column8: both of which displayed a knack for unifying the whole work by exploring and re-exploring the same themes in different contexts. And in the Endless Pause does the same

column1: One of the biggest surprises of the score is how openly dramatic it is given the composer's past work. The solo cello that moans up out of the droning morass of ""Escape"" before being swallowed by a hideous electro-acoustic groan is among the most nakedly emotional sounds I've heard in his music. It has the glacial beauty of a lot of his past work without the glacial pacing. Which is not to say it's better

column3: but it is more immediate
column4:
whether or not you're watching those civilization-building rodents.

column1: Nigeria Afrobeat Special kicks off with an actual Fela Ransome Kuti & His Africa 70 recording: The single version of ""Who're You""

column1: Untold is one of two producers featured on both Sub:stance and Elevator Music
column2: two new compilations that serve as mini-anthropologies of dubstep in 2010-- who's making it and what it's sounding like. Elevator Music is a set of unmixed
column3: exclusive tracks released on Fabric Recordings
column4: a label linked to the London club of the same name (a former cold storage building; #2 on DJmag.com's Top 100 Clubs of 2009). Sub:stance is named for a dubstep-themed night at Berlin's Berghain (a former power station; #1)
column5: led by producer and Hotflush Recordings founder Paul Rose
column6: aka Scuba.

column1: Elevator Music is brighter; Sub:stance is deeper and more atmospheric. What sounds better to you probably depends somewhat on temperament. If you don't think house music is chintzy shit for drunk clubbers
column2: EM might be more appealing to you-- I certainly have more fun listening to it. If you like dubstep's mannered beauty and stiff upper lip
column3: try Sub:stance. Even EM's most downtempo track (Om Unit's ""Encoded"") has a sizzling
column4: up-front feel that Sub:stance's liveliest track (Joy Orbison's ""Hyph Mngo"") doesn't. There's certainly some overlap-- Martyn's ""Friedrichstrasse"" (from EV) could work on Sub:stance
column5: and Ramadanman's ""Tempest"" (from Sub:stance) could work on EV: both tracks blur more lines than they draw.

column1: I'll admit that I'm not sensitive to mixing when I'm listening to a disc like Sub:stance-- I hear it more as a set of songs than a demonstration of his DJ prowess. Still
column2: that doesn't bring Sub:stance down at all-- it's a listenable and succinct lead-in to a lot of what's happening in dubstep
column3: and I'd definitely recommend it to people who get freaked out and angry at the mere mention of dance-music subgenres. Elevator Music isn't perfect either-- it's a scattered record that does more to undercut a definition of dubstep than to help define it. But when I hear what guys like Untold are doing-- ""No-One Likes a Smart Arse"" for Sub:stance and the standout ""Bad Girls"" for EM-- I start to feel like that's part of the point: to set its weird little bastards running across the dancefloor
column4:
just to see what happens.

Within a group of musicians already notoriously peeved about a lack of respect

""Stereotype""'s slowly gathering strings and ""Arise""'s alien synthesizers sound deluxe and deeply musical. ""Roaming"" contains a bobbing jazz bassline; ""Simpatico"" is a keyboard-helmed house jam that is modest and self-contained. Frictionalism spreads out over three and a half hours but it contains few anthems and fewer indulgences
column3: Shakir preferring instead to provide to just lay in the grooves of his regenerating hop.

column1: Shakir is known for incorporating hip-hop into his productions
column2: and while the vast majority of Frictionalism exists on the techno axis
column3: it'd be easy to see J Dilla latch onto the symphonic jazz of ""Detroit State of Mind"" or Madlib onto the smoky Eastern funk of the spectacularly titled ""Things Come and Go"". Influence is a strange concept with an artist like Shakir

column1: Shakir is at a crossroads. Shakir fondly compares techno producers with jazz musicians for their ability to extend their creative lives. Frictionalism gives him the opportunity to continue in front of an audience

but it also exposes an already rewarding creative life that deserves more company.

column6: rapid-fire synths for propulsion and quick tonal shifts to add color. This is precisely the kind of music some would criticize as robotic and unfeeling

column1: Supergrass are at an all-covers-album point in their careers-- with 16 years and six studio albums under their belts
column2: the band have experienced a gradual side down the UK charts in recent years (with 2008's Diamond Hoo Ha barely cracking the Top 20)
column3: and now exist in that middle-aged purgatory between NME buzz band and MOJO lifetime-achievement award recipients. They're also entering this decade as independent recording artists

So you can totally understand founding members Gaz Coombes and Danny Goffey (with producer Nigel Godrich in tow) wanting to cast those uncertainties aside and get back to where they once belonged via their all-covers project the HotRats. But what seems like a perfectly swell concept for a surprise gig at the local pub-- where sloshed spectators can join in on the hero worship-- feels much more suspect when reified into a permanent record.

column1: For one
column2: Turn Ons' song selection doesn't reveal anything we didn't already know about Coombes and Goffey-- they have and always will be dedicated pop scholars mining the historical classic-rock contiunuum
column3: from Ray Davies and Syd Barrett to David Bowie and Roxy Music to Elvis Costello and The Cure (all of whom have signature tracks featured here). But the real problem with Turn Ons isn't so much the predictable sources as the fact that the HotRats don't really do a whole lot with them. The minor touch-ups heard here don't exactly constitute a bold attempt to put their own stamp on the material: the Velvet Undergrond's ""I Can't Stand It"" is given an electric-boogie boost befitting of the Velvets' 1970s glam-rock progeny
column4: the Cure's ""Love Cats"" gets a beefed-up swing beat
column5: while the punk-rock classics (Gang of Four's ""Damaged Goods"" and a nudge-wink
column6: self-reflexive take on the Sex Pistols' ""EMI"") are powered by acoustic guitars instead of electric. The HotRats are most successful at transforming Squeeze's ""Up the Junction"" into a piano-ballad reverie
column7: but such inspired gestures are outnumbered by the more ill-advised augmentations: a version of Roxy Music's ""Love Is the Drug"" that neuters the original's discotheque groove into sexless spasms
column8: or an otherwise straight-forward take on Bowie's ""Queen Bitch"" that slathers on an ornate string arrangement completely at odds with the song's streetwise swagger.

column6: paisley-hued outtake from The Who Sell Out. But while the novelty works on the verses
column7: it leaves Coombes unsure of what to do with the chorus
column8: thereby sapping the song of its greatest attribute: the opportunity to shout along with the titular slogan.

column4:
it actually would've been a lot more interesting to hear Coombes and Goffey try their hand at some 10-minute jazz-rock jams than another note-for-note version of ""Pump It Up"".
